SUMMARY:  LATE FILED. On March 15, 2016, Dennis Quinn, Chief Operating Officer of Joule Assets Inc. (Joule Assets), met with Cmmr. Peterman in San Francisco.  Also present were David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Mike Gordon, Chief Executive Officer of Joule Assets. Quinn provided an overview of Joule Assets and its role as manager of the Energy Reduction Asset (ERA) Fund, a private equity fund that invests in energy reduction solutions in small and medium commercial facilities, including energy efficiency.  Quinn highlighted the ERA Fund’s focus on performance-based solutions using M&V for each participating site. Quinn described how Joule Assets achieves deployment through development of a network of contractor and technology partners; incorporates best practices, such as ICP certification with its projects and incorporates investment-grade backed performance insurance for its portfolio of projects. Quinn noted that the ERA Fund is interested in investing in projects availing of the principles of both SB 350 and AB 802. Joule Assets stated that it has been actively involved in providing input as California Alternative Energy and Advanced Transportation Financing Authority develops credit enhancement programs to support further energy efficiency investment to meet the objectives of SB 350.  Quinn reinforced that timely measurement and verification and baseline methodology development will be key to AB 802 success. Quinn encouraged the Commission to let the market demonstrate that solutions exist today for success. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On March 16, 2016, Beckie Menten, Director of Customer Programs of Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Cmmr. Peterman in San Francisco.  Also present were David Gamson and Joanna Gubman, advisors to Cmmr. Peterman; and Shalini Swaroop, Regulatory and Legislative Counsel, for MCE. Description: SUMMARY: on January 26, 2016, Donald Gilligan, President of the National Association of Energy Service Companies (ESCO) met with Cmmr. Peterman in San Francisco. Also present were David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, and Mr. Sperberg and Mr. Mahoney of ESCO.  ESCO representatives discussed the application of AB 802 to energy efficiency (EE) programs. ESCO representatives said that they believe that AB 802 offers the Commission an historic opportunity to simplify the administration of California EE programs, which has become unnecessarily complex over the past ten years, particularly in the area of savings baselines and EM&V. Gilligan said that this complexity makes the California programs less effective than in other states.  ESCO participants provided examples of projects and programs which they believe are hindered by the current Title 24 and Industry Standard Practice baselines. The ESCO participants urged the Commission to address the issue of the workload of the Energy Division, and stated that the current workload can result in untimely delivery of key reports and a growing lag between the accelerating innovation in EE technology and the incorporation of these technologies into EE programs.  Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  On October 29, 2015, Terry Fry, Senior Vice President, Nexant, Inc. (Nexant), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present were Mushtaq Ahmad, Senior Manager, Milena Usabiaga, Project Manager, and Jack Stoddard, attorney, for Nexant.  At the meeting, Nexant briefed on a staff disposition that would deny energy efficiency savings claimed for a Nexant industrial retrocommissioning project. Nexant explained that air compressor projects represent significant energy efficiency savings potential, and it is not industry standard practice to repair air leaks in air compressor systems unless the air compressors are not meeting the customer's end use needs. Nextant further explained that Title 24 is not triggered in this instance and that Staff's characterization of the air compressor project as a "to code" project was incorrect.  Nextant also stated that it is prohibited from communicating directly with staff regarding errors in the disposition; and that because Nexant is a third party implementer, and not the Program Administrator, there is no clear process for it to appeal or seek review of the staff disposition.

SUMMARY:  On April 1, 2015, Anthony Harrison, Policy Director of the California Energy Efficiency Industry Council (Efficiency Council) met with Cmmr. Peterman.  Also present were Julie Fitch, Jennifer Kalafut and Melicia Charles, advisors to Cmmr. Peterman, and Ben Bodell, law student extern for Cmmr. Peterman; Jeanne Clinton, Governor's CPUC advisor on energy efficiency; and Steve Schiller, Board Chair Emeritus, for the Efficiency Council.  Efficiency Council's representatives discussed Assembly Bill 1330, a bill currently introduced in the  
California Legislature, which is sponsored by the Efficiency Council.  The Efficiency Council representatives explained that this legislation could work in conjunction with the goal setting process within the proceeding, as it simply establishes a "floor" by which energy savings through efficiency must be achieved.  Schiller explained that since energy efficiency is a resource that all Californians can benefit from, the Efficiency Council felt that it was important to ensure disadvantage communities were included in a major way in the state's energy efficiency efforts. A written material (attached to the notice) was used.
